sen.j: 十刹（じっせつ）とは、中国・日本における禅林（禅宗寺院）の格式であり、五山の下・諸山の上。
sen.e: Jissetsu is a form of Zen temples in China and Japan, below the Gozan (Zen temples highly ranked by the government) and above the Shozan (zen temples other than Gozan (five great zen temples) and Jissatsu (ten important temples of Rinzai sect))

Jissetsu is a form of Zen temple in China and Japan, below the Gozan (Zen temples highly ranked by the government) and above the Shozan (zen temples other than Gozan (five great zen temples) and Jissatsu (ten important temples of the Rinzai sect)).

Jissetsu is a form of Zen temple in China and Japan, below the Gozan (Zen temples highly ranked by the government) and above the Shozan (zen temples other than Gozan (five great zen temples) and Jissetsu (ten important temples of the Rinzai sect)).

sen.j: 元来は南宋の寧宗_(宋)がインドの5精舎10塔所の故事に倣って「五山」とともに「十刹」を定めて保護を与えたのが由来と言われている。
sen.e: Originally, the origin of the Jissetsu is that Neiso (Ningzong) of the Southern Sung Dynasty imitated the tradition of India's 5 Shoja (a hall where priests practice asceticism, like a temple) and ten pagodas, decided the "Gozan" and "Jissetsu" and protected them.

Originally, the origin of the Jissetsu is that Neiso (Ningzong) of the Southern Sung dynasty imitated the tradition of India's five Shoja (a hall where priests practice asceticism, like a temple) and ten pagodas, decided the "Gozan" and "Jissetsu" and protected them.

Originally, the origin of the Jissetsu is that Neiso (Ningzong) of the Southern Sung dynasty imitated the tradition of India's five Shoja (a hall where priests practice asceticism, like a temple) and ten pagodas, decided the 'Gozan' and 'Jissetsu' and protected them.

sen.j: 日本では、建武の新政の段階で既に南禅寺・浄妙寺（両寺は後に五山に昇格）・万寿寺 (大分市)が「十刹」に指定されていたことが明らかとされており、「十刹」成立を鎌倉時代末期とするのが通説とされている。
sen.e: In Japan, it is clear that during the Kenmu Restoration Nanzen-ji Temple, Jomyo-ji Temple (both temples were elevated afterwards to Gozan), Manju-ji Temple (Oita City) were already designated as "Jissetsu", it is accepted that the "Jissetsu" were established in the late Kamakura Period.

In Japan, it is clear that during the Kenmu Restoration Nanzen-ji Temple, Jomyo-ji Temple (both temples were later elevated to Gozan), Manju-ji Temple (Oita City) were already designated as "Jissetsu," it is accepted that the "Jissetsu" were established during the late Kamakura period.

In Japan, it is clear that during the Kenmu Restoration Nanzen-ji Temple, Jomyo-ji Temple (both temples were later elevated to Gozan), Manju-ji Temple (Oita City) were already designated as 'Jissetsu,' it is accepted that the 'Jissetsu' were established during the late Kamakura period.

sen.j: 室町幕府によって「天下十刹」が定められたものの、その時々に応じて入る寺院や順位などが変動した。
sen.e: Although the Muromachi Shogunate decided the "ten great temples in Japan", but depending on the occasion the temples and their rank changed.
Although the Muromachi shogunate decided the "ten great temples in Japan," but the temples and their rank were subject to change depending on the occasion.

Although the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) decided the 'ten great temples in Japan,' but the temples and their rank were subject to change depending on the occasion.

sen.j: そこで至徳 (日本)3年7月10日_(旧暦)（1386年）に五山制度の改革にあわせて十刹制度の改革を行って、「京都十刹」と「関東十刹（鎌倉十刹）」に分けられて京都と関東地方（鎌倉以外の寺院も含む）がそれぞれ10ヶ寺ずつ定められた。
sen.e: In 1386 together with the reform of the Gozan system the Jissetsu system was also reformed and divided into the "Kyoto Jissetsu" and the "Kanto Jissetsu" (Kamakura Jissetsu), and ten temples were decided respectively in Kyoto and the Kanto region (including temples outside Kamakura).

In 1386, together with the reform of the Gozan system, the Jissetsu system was reformed and divided into the "Kyoto Jissetsu" and the "Kanto Jissetsu" (Kamakura Jissetsu), and ten temples were decided respectively in Kyoto and the Kanto region (including temples outside Kamakura).

On August 13, 1386, together with the reform of the Gozan system, the Jissetsu system was reformed and divided into the 'Kyoto Jissetsu' and the 'Kanto Jissetsu' (Kamakura Jissetsu), and ten temples were decided respectively in Kyoto and the Kanto region (including temples outside Kamakura).

sen.j: だが、地方の寺院は「天下十刹」に入っていたものでも結果的にその資格を取り上げられたためにこれに強く反発し、後に枠外として「十刹」に追加される寺院も現れた。
sen.e: However, among the regional temples there appeared temples that had been included in the "ten great temples of Japan", but had been eventually deprived of their designation and therefore protested strongly, and afterwards these temples were added to the "Jissetsu" as an exception.

However, among the regional temples there were some that had been included in the "ten great temples of Japan" but had eventually been deprived of their designation and therefore protested strongly, and subsequently these temples were added to the "Jissetsu" as exceptions.

However, among the regional temples there were some that had been included in the 'ten great temples of Japan' but had eventually been deprived of their designation and therefore protested strongly, and subsequently these temples were added to the 'Jissetsu' as exceptions.

sen.j: そのため、明応元年（1490年）には46、更に後には60ヶ寺まで増加することになった。
sen.e: Therefore, in 1490 their number increased to 46 and afterwards to 60 temples.
Therefore, in 1490 their number increased to 46 and later to 60 temples.
Therefore, in 1490 their number increased to 46 and later to 60 temples.

sen.j: 天下十刹
暦応年間
浄妙寺 - 第一位（→後に五山昇格）
sen.e: Jomyo-ji Temple - second rank (afterwards elevated to Gozan)
Jomyo-ji Temple: Second rank (afterwards elevated to Gozan)
Jomyo-ji Temple: First rank (afterwards elevated to Gozan)

sen.j: 禅興寺 - 第二位
聖福寺 (福岡市) - 第三位
万寿寺 - 第四位（→後に五山昇格）
sen.e: Manju-ji Temple - fifth rank (afterwards elevated to Gozan)
Manju-ji Temple: Fifth rank (afterwards elevated to Gozan)
Manju-ji Temple: Fourth rank (afterwards elevated to Gozan)

安国寺_(京都) - 第四位（→後に廃寺）

Ankoku-ji Temple (Kyoto City): Fourth rank (temple subsequently abandoned)

sen.j: 宝幢寺 - 第五位

Fumon-ji Temple: Sixth rank (temple subsequently abandoned)

Kogaku-ji Temple: Seventh rank (temple subsequently abandoned)
